```{r}
# Compute rate per 10,000
table1 %>%
  mutate(rate = cases / population * 10000)

table1 %>%
  count(year, wt = cases)

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(table1, aes(year, cases)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = country), colour = "grey50") +
  geom_point(aes(colour = country))
```

## 4.5.1 Lengthening datasets
```{r}
billboard |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("wk"),
    names_to = "week",
    values_to = "rank"
)
```

```{r}
df <- tribble(
  ~id,  ~bp1, ~bp2,
   "A",  100,  120,
   "B",  140,  115,
   "C",  120,  125
)
```

```{r}
df |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = bp1:bp2,
    names_to = "measurement",
    values_to = "value"
)
```

## 4.5.3 Widening datasets
```{r}
cms_patient_experience
```

```{r}
cms_patient_experience |>
  distinct(measure_cd, measure_title)
```

```{r}
cms_patient_experience |>
  pivot_wider(
     names_from = measure_cd,
    values_from = prf_rate
  )
```

```{r}
cms_patient_experience |>
  pivot_wider(
    id_cols = starts_with("org"),
    names_from = measure_cd,
    values_from = prf_rate
)
```

## 4.5.4 Pivoting wider
```{r}
df <- tribble(
  ~id, ~measurement, ~value,
  "A",        "bp1",    100,
  "B",        "bp1",    140,
  "B",        "bp2",    115,
  "A",        "bp2",    120,
  "A",        "bp3",    105
)
```


```{r}
df |>
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = measurement,
    values_from = value
  )

```

```{r}
df |>
  distinct(measurement) |>
  pull()
```

```{r}
df |>
  select(-measurement, -value) |>
  distinct()
```

```{r}
df |>
  select(-measurement, -value) |>
  distinct() |>
  mutate(x = NA, y = NA, z = NA)
```

##4.5.5 Exercises
```{r}
## 1. Why are pivot_longer() and pivot_wider() not perfectly symmetrical? Carefully consider the following example.
stocks <- tibble(
year = c(2015, 2015, 2016, 2016), half =c( 1, 2, 1, 2), return = c(1.88, 0.59, 0.92, 0.17)
)
stocks %>%
pivot_wider(names_from = year, values_from = return) %>%
  pivot_longer(`2015`:`2016`, names_to = "year", values_to =
"return")
```

```{r}
## 2. why does this code fail?
table4a %>%
  pivot_longer(c(1999, 2000), names_to = "year", values_to =
"cases")
```

```{r}
## 3. Consider the sample tibble below. Do you need to make it wider or longer? What are the variables?
preg <- tribble(
  ~pregnant, ~male, ~female,
  "yes",     NA,    10,
  "no",      20,    12
)
```

## 4.5.6 Separating and uniting data tables
```{r}
table3
```

```{r}
table3 %>%
  separate(rate, into = c("cases", "population"))
```

```{r}
table3 %>%
  separate(rate, into = c("cases", "population"), sep = "/")
```

```{r}
table3 %>%
  separate(rate, into = c("cases", "population"), convert = TRUE)
```

```{r}
table3 %>%
  separate(year, into = c("century", "year"), sep = 2)
```

## Explicit missing values
```{r}
treatment <- tribble(
  ~person,           ~treatment, ~response,
  "Derrick Whitmore", 1,         7,
  NA,                 2,         10,
  NA,                 3,         NA,
  "Katherine Burke",  1,         4
)
```


```{r}
treatment |>
  fill(everything())
```

## 4.6.2 Fixed values
```{r}
x <- c(1, 4, 5, 7, NA)
coalesce(x, 0)
```

```{r}
x <- c(1, 4, 5, 7, -99)
na_if(x, -99)
```

## 4.6.3 NaN
```{r}
x <- c(NA, NaN)
x * 10
x == 1
is.na(x)
```

## 4.6.4 Implicit missing values
```{r}
stocks <- tibble(
year = c(2020, 2020, 2020, 2020, 2021, 2021, 2021), qtr =c( 1, 2, 3, 4, 2, 3, 4), price = c(1.88, 0.59, 0.35, NA, 0.92, 0.17, 2.66)
)
```


```{r}
stocks |>
  pivot_wider(
     names_from = qtr,
    values_from = price
  )
```
